document.docTitle: Taxonomic account and phylogenetic relationships of the species of the Neotropical social wasp genus Chartergus Lepeletier, 1836 (Vespidae: Polistinae: Epiponini)

emphasis.docTitle:
Taxonomic account and phylogenetic relationships of the species of the Neotropical social wasp genus
Chartergus Lepeletier, 1836
( Vespidae : Polistinae: Epiponini)

subSection.paragraph: ALEXANDRE SOMAVILLA 1* , MARCOS ARAGÃO 2 , PAULO CÉZAR SALGADO BARROSO 3 , JAMES M. CARPENTER 4 & RODOLPHO SANTOS TELLES MENEZES 5

1 Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia, Coordenação de Biodiversidade, Manaus, AM, Brazil
Ễ
alexandresomavilla@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-8174-7418

2 Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia, Coordenação de Biodiversidade, Manaus, AM, Brazil
Ễ
marcosaragaowasp@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0001-7333-0172

3 Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia, Coordenação de Biodiversidade, Manaus, AM, Brazil
Ễ
pc.salgadobarroso@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-0358-5142

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: American Museum of Natural History, Division of Invertebrate Zoology, New York City, USA

subSection.paragraph: Ễ carpente@amnh.org; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6754-8028

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Universidade Estadual de Santa Cruz, Departamento de Ciências Biológicas, Ilhéus, Brazil

subSection.paragraph: Ễ rstmenezes@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6612-3543

The Neotropical social wasp genus
Chartergus
is reviewed and comparative diagnoses, images of type material, and an updated identification key for species are presented. To investigate the phylogenetic relationships within the genus, we used a combined dataset of morphological characters, nest architecture traits, and molecular data. The results revealed the following relationships among the
Chartergus
species: (
C. globiventris
+ (
C. artifex
+
C. metanotalis
)).

Chartergus Lepeletier, 1836
is a neotropical genus of swarm-founding social wasps that comprises only three species:
Chartergus artifex (Christ, 1791)
( type species),
Chartergus globiventris de Saussure, 1854
, and
Chartergus metanotalis Richards, 1978
. The genus is primarily distinguished by the head with occipital carina present dorsolaterally, absence of anteromedial fovea on the pronotum, metanotum with medial tubercle, propodeum with dorsolateral carinae, and metasomal segment I compressed ( Richards 1978 ). This genus is widely distributed in South America, from Colombia to South of Mid-West Brazil ( Richards 1978 ;
Somavilla et al . 2021a
). Their nests are arboreal, frequently attached to a tree branch high above the ground, and exhibit typical phragmocyttarous structure, consisting of multiple combs sessile on its own envelope, which are usually rigid and composed of long white fibers. Moreover, the nests are cylindrical or broadening downwards with a flattened-conical bottom, and grow rapidly through the construction of several layers. The entrance hole is simple and located in the ventral center of the nest, which may become funnel shaped. It is little more than one wasp’s headwidth in diameter and aligns to form an internal passage between combs ( Richards 1978 ; Wenzel 1998 ).

According to Richards (1978) , the genus shows significant structural diversity in important morphological characters. Currently, there is no phylogenetic hypothesis for
Chartergus
, and the only identification key to the genus is provided by Richards (1978) . Therefore, here we present comparative diagnoses, images of type material, and an updated identification key for the three
Chartergus species.
Additionally, we propose a phylogenetic hypothesis based on molecular and morphological data for the genus and a reassessment of their geographical distribution.

We examined the type material of
Chartergus
species, including the holotype of
Chartergus globiventris
, two paratypes of
Chartergus metanotalis
(the holotype was lost in the fire at the National Museum of Rio de Janeiro), and the holotype of
Chartergus tuberculatus Cameron, 1906
=
Chartergus artifex
(the holotype of the latter is lost). The type specimen of
C. tuberculatus
is deposited in the Natural History Museum (NHM—London, England ). Additionally, we analyzed specimens from the American Museum of Natural History ( AMNH — New York , USA ) and the Zoology Museum of the Universidade de S„o Paulo ( MZSP —S„o Paulo, Brazil ). We used all of this material to provide comparative diagnoses and update the identification key provided by Richards (1978) . Moreover, we analyzed specimens collected by Malaise traps during a survey in the Northern Region of Brazil for the “Biodiversity of Insects of the Amazon (Rede BIA)” project (for details see
Somavilla et al. 2020
). Those specimens are deposited in the Invertebrate Collection of Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia ( INPA —Manaus, Brazil ).

We constructed a matrix consisting of 22 morphological characters, including 13 characters from adult females, six characters from adult males (including male genitalia), and three characters related to nest architecture (adapted from Andena & Carpenter 2012 ) and directly observed on nests deposited in the AMNH collection. We studied morphological characters under a Nikon SMZ645 stereo microscope with an accessory magnifying lens of Nikon G-AL 2x. We obtained images of each species with the aid of a Leica DMC4500 digital camera coupled to a Leica M205A stereomicroscope with a self-assembly system, using the Leica Application Suite v.4.10.0-Montage® software. Nest images come from the AMNH database (Wasp Nest Database, Invertebrate Zoology, American Museum of Natural History—https://emu-prod.amnh.org/imulive/iz/iz.html). We edited the images and assembled the plates using the software ADOBE PHOTOSHOP® CS6 v.6.1.

We generated a distribution map for
Chartergus
by compiling data from literature sources and collection records obtained from museums (see Supplementary Material). We georeferenced the locality information from each specimen using the on-line Google Maps Platform. The geographical coordinates were converted to decimal degrees and imported into Quantum-GIS v2.18.18 (Open Source Geospatial Foundation Project, Beaverton, OR, USA ), a free and open source geographic information system to produce a distribution map. Asterisk (*) in the distribution topic means new record of the occurrence for the species.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Chartergus Lepeletier, 1836
, Hist. Nat. Ins. Hym. 1: 542, genus

Type species:
Vespa nidulans Fabricius, 1793
[=
Vespa artifex surinamensis Christ, 1791
], by subsequent designation of Blanchard, 1840, Hist. Nat. Anim. Artic. 3: 395.

Chatergus Erichson, 1838, Arch. Naturgesch. 4 (2): 237; H. von Ihering, 1927, Gesch. Atlant. Ozeans: 180. Incorrect spelling of
Chartergus Lepeletier.
Chartoteuchium B̂rner, 1919, Biol. Zbl. 39: 186, genus. Nomen nudum .

Chartegus Bequaert, 1949 (1948), Bol. Entomol. Venezolana 7: 131. Incorrect spelling of
Chartergus Lepeletier.

Chartergus Richards, 1978
, Soc. Wasps Am.: 132; (syn.: Chartoteuchium B̂rner).

Type species:
Vespa chartaria Olivier, 1792
[=
Vespa artifex surinamensis Christ, 1791
], by original designation.
Fig. 1A–H , 4 , 5

Vespa artifex surinamensis Christ, 1791
, Naturgesch. Ins.: 226, pl. 20—“ Surinam ” ( type lost).

Vespa chartaria Olivier, 1792
, Encyc. Méthod. 6 (2): 687—“de Cayenne & de Surinam ” ( type lost).—Bequaert, 1938, Rev. Entomol., Rio de Janeiro 9: 114 (syn.:
Vespa nidulans Fabricius
; designated as type of
Epipona
).

Vespa nidulans Fabricius, 1793
, Entomol. Syst. 2: 271—[ French Guiana ] “Cajennae” (? Paris).—Coquebert, 1799, Illus. Icon. Ins.: 24, pl. VI fig. 3A.—Latreille, 1829, Crust. Arach. Ins. 2: 339.—Carpenter, 1999, Am. Mus. Novitat. 3259: 8 (note on type ).

Epipona nidulans ; Latreille, 1802
, Hist. Nat. Crust. Ins. 3: 365; 1809, Gen. Crust. Ins. 4: pl. XIV fig. 6; 1824, Mém. Mus. Hist. Nat. Paris 11: 316 (compared to
Polistes lecheguana
n. sp. ).—Curtis, 1844, Trans. Linn. Soc. London 19: 258 ( Epipone [!]; syn.:
E. chartaria “Lat.
”).

Vespa chartifex Vallot, 1802
, Concord. Syst.: 171—[ French Guiana ] “ Cayenne ” ( type lost).

Epipona chartaria ; Latreille, 1804, Hist. Nat. Crust. Ins. 13: 102, pl. XIV figs. 6–7; 1805, Hist. Nat. Crust. Ins. 13: 349, pl. CII figs. 6–7 (“Epipone cartonnière”), 1806, Hist. Nat. Crust. Ins. 1: Tab. XIV fig. 6 ( Epipone [!]).—Bequaert, 1938, Rev. Entomol., Rio de Janeiro 9: 114 (syns.:
V. nidulans Fabricius
,
V. artifex surinamensis Christ
,
V. chartifex Vallot
,
C. tuberculatus Cameron
; Guyana ; Brazil ; Bolivia ).

Polistes nidulans
; Lepeletier and Serville, 1825, Encyc. Méthod. 10: 172.—Guérin, 1844, Icon. Règne Anim. Ins., Atlas: pl. 72, fig. 7.
Chartergus nidulans ; Lepeletier, 1836, Hist. Nat. Ins. Hym. 1: 546.—White, 1841, Ann. Mag. Nat. Hist. 7: 315.—Casolari and Casolari Moreno, 1979, Boll. Mus. Zool. Univ. Torino (4): 135 (list).

Chartergus chartarius ; de Saussure, 1854, Ét. Fam. Vesp. 2: 217 (key), 220 (syns.:
V. artifex surinamensis Christ
,
V. chartifex Vallot
,
V. nidulans Fabricius
).—M̂bius, 1856, Nester Gesell. Wespen: 34 (key), pl. XIII fig. 6.—Fox, 1898, Proc. Acad. Nat. Sci. Philad.: 457 ( Brazil : Amazonas, Mato Grosso ).—Dalla Torre, 1904, Gen. Ins. 19: 85 (cat.).—Ducke, 1904, Bol. Mus. Goeldi, Pará 4: 324, 328 (key), 334 ( Brazil ).—Cameron, 1906, Invert. Pacif. 1: 156 (compared to
tuberculatus
n. sp. ).—Ducke, 1910, Ann. Hist.-Nat. Mus. Natl. Hung. 8: 484 (syns.:
V. artifex surinamensis Christ
,
V. nidulans Fabricius
,
V. chartifex Vallot
,
C. globiventris de Saussure
,
C. tuberculatus Cameron
; female, male; French Guiana ; Brazil ).—Cameron, 1912, Timehri (3) 2: 219 ( Guyana ).—Bequaert, 1944, Bull. Mus. Comp. Zool. 94: 274 (list); 1949 (1948), Bol. Entomol. Venez. 7: 131 ( Chartegus [!]; Venezuela ).—Machado and Hebling, 1972, in C. da Cruz-Landim et al. , Homenagem à Warwick E. Kerr: 199–204 (caste polymorphism).— Richards, 1978 , Soc.Wasps Am.: 132 (key), 134, fig. 68.—Overal, 1978, Bol. Mus. Para. Emílio Goeldi (N. S.), Zool. 94: 9 (list).—Raw, 1989, Maracá Rainfor. Proj., Invert. Limnol., Prelim. Rep.: 35 ( Brazil ), 36 ( Chatergus [!]; distr.); 1989, Maracá Rainfor. Proj., Invert. Limnol., Prelim. Rep.: 41 (habitat preference).— Carpenter and van der Vecht, 1991, Ann. Carnegie Mus. 60 (3): 221 (note on material seen by Fox).—Almeida and Castro, 1991, Acta Biol. Par., Curitiba 20: 47 (coll. list).—Sarmiento, 1994, Rev. Biol. Trop. 42 (1/2): 358 (list).—Garcete-Barrett, 1999, Avispas Soc. Parag.: 30, fig.—Cooper, 2000, Entomol. Mon. Mag. 136: 196 (nest association with
Azteca
;
Agelaia pallidiventris
;
Polybia rejecta
,
P. singularis
,
Synoeca virginea
, and Icteridae).

Chartergus tuberculatus Cameron, 1906
, Invert. Pacif. 1: 155, male—“Rio Branco, Obidos, Brazil ” (London).

Chartergus artifex
; Carpenter, 1999, Am. Mus. Novitat. 3259: 1, 8.

Diagnosis. Clypeus wider than long, more transverse; clypeus touching the eyes for an extension equal than width of antennal socket; midlength gena equal to or wider than eye; genal margin clearly sinuate a little below the middle of eye, beyond it curved so that the gena becomes very broad again; humeri pronounced; pronotum with an anterior pale transverse band, and with prominence near ventral corner longer and more acute; pronotal fovea absent; scrobal furrow with less regular and usually weaker carinae; metanotum compressed; central tubercle of metanotum stronger; metanotum with a pale band across the top half, rarely partly black here; keel on dorsal half of propodeal angles longer; first metasomal segment wider than long; second metasomal segment as long as wide; usually the largest species in the genus
Chartergus
.

Remarks.
Chartergus artifex (Christ, 1791)
=
Vespa artifex surinamensis Christ, 1791
, Naturgesch. Ins.: 226, pl. 20—“Surinam” (the type is lost).
Vespa chartaria Olivier, 1791: 687
. Types, French Guiana: Cayenne; Surinam (lost).
Vespa nidulans Fabricius, 1793: 271
. Types, French Guiana: Cayenne, (MNHN, Paris, lost).
Vespa chartifex Vallot, 1802: 171
. Types, French Guiana: Cayenne (lost). According to Richards the types of these three synonyms of
C. artifex
are possibly lost and the only type in museums has been examined by us:
Chartergus tuberculatus Cameron, 1906: 155
. Holotype , BRAZIL : PA, Obidos, Rio Branco, (NHM).

Chartergus artifex (Christ, 1791)

Chartergus tuberculatus
[currently
Chartergus artifex
]—E: lateral. F: dorsal. G: original label.

subSubSection.paragraph: Fig. 2A–H , 4 , 5
Chartergus chartarius var. globiventris ; Ducke, 1910, Ann. Hist.-Nat. Mus. Natl. Hung. 8: 484, fig. 5.
Epipona globiventris ; Bequaert, 1938, Rev. Entomol., Rio de Janeiro 9: 115 ( Brazil ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Chartergus globiventris de Saussure, 1854
—A: lateral view. B: dorsal view. C: face, frontal view. D: nest. Holotype of
Chartergus globiventris
—E: lateral. F: dorsal. G: gaster, dorsal view. H: original label.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Clypeus wider than long, less transverse; clypeus touching the eyes for an extension shorter than width of antennal socket; midlength gena equal to wider than eye; genal margin hardly sinuate, sloping up to the mandibles at its lowest point where the gena is also broadest; humeri pronounced; pronotum black, without anterior color band, and with prominence near ventral corner shorter and less acute but often more raised; pronotal fovea absent; scrobal furrow with less regular and usually weaker carinae; metanotum compressed; central tubercle of metanotum very weak, often hardly noticeable; metanotum with a pale band across the top half, rarely partly black here; keel on top half of propodeal angles shorter; first metasomal segment wider than long; second metasomal segment as long as wide. It can be easily differentiated from
C. artifex
and
C. metanotalis
because it has the central tubercle of the metanotum very weak; and is the smallest species in the genus
Chartergus
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Fig. 3A–H , 4 , 5

Chartergus metanotalis
Richards, 1978
, Soc. Wasps Am. : 132 (key), 135, fig. 70, female, male—“ BRAZIL : MT, base camp, 12°50’S , 51°47’W ” ( holotype female Rio de Janeiro ); also from elsewhere in Mato Grosso , Goiás , Acre , Pará ; and Ecuador.—Almeida and Castro , 1991, Acta Biol. Par., Curitiba 20: 43 (note on type material).— Sarmiento , 1994, Rev. Biol. Trop. 42 (1/2): 359 ( Colombia : Amazonas ; list).— Garcete-Barrett , 1999, Avispas Soc. Parag.: 30, fig.

Diagnosis. Clypeus wider than long, more transverse; clypeus touching the eyes for an extension equal than width of antennal socket; midlength gena equal to wider than eye; genal margin usually scarcely sinuate below middle, ventrally bending upwards and running in an almost straight line towards mandibles; humeri pronounced; pronotum with apical whitish yellow band, usually incomplete and stronger in the middle; pronotal keel with a whitish yellow band; without pronotal fovea; scrobal furrow with more or less regular carinae metanotum compressed; central tubercle of metanotum stronger; metanotum nearly always entirely black or with small yellow spots on the sides; first metasomal segment wider than long; second metasomal segment as long as wide.
Chartergus metanotalis
is structurally very close to
C. artifex
but on the average a little smaller, the clypeus and propodeum are usually more coarsely sculptured; and it differs from
C. globiventris
in the much stronger metanotal tubercle.

Type material examined. Paratype : 1♁ BRAZIL : Mato Grosso , 12°50’S , 51°47’W , Cerrado, N[est] 11, 20.ii.1968 , O.W. Richards [leg.], R.S. & R.G.S. Expedition, B.M. 1968-260), NHMUK 010817929 (NHM). 1♀ , 5♁ same date. Paratype : 1♀ , BRAZIL : Goiás , Cristalândia, 01.x.1968 , W. Hamilton [leg.] [label],
Chartergus chartarius W. Hamilton
[det] [label],
Chartergus metanotalis Richards
, Paratype [label], MZSP 84283 ( MZSP ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4. Map showing the current geographic distribution of
Chartergus species.
For locality information see Supplementary material S1.

FIGURE 5. Phylogenetic relationships of
Chartergus species
inferred by Maximum Likelihood (A) and Maximum Parsimony (B) analysis using COI mitochondrial and morphological data. Values at the nodes represent Shimodaira-Hasegawa approximate likelihood ratio test/parametric ultrafast bootstrap (left) and symmetric resampling (right) supports as reported by IQ-Tree (A) and TNT (B), respectively.

/ Luminosa Móvel, J.A. Rafael , R.J.P. Machado & A. Silva leg . ( 1♀ , INPA )
;
FLOREST Canutama , Terra Firme ,
07.v.2013
, -64.5515 -6.5069 , Oliveira & Somavilla leg . ( 1♀ , INPA )
;
Pará , Repartimento Vicinal 08 , 04°26’42”S- 49°54’25”W ,
28.xi.2001
, Malaise, J.A. Rafael & J. Vidal leg . /
Chartergus metanotalis Silveira
(det.) ( 1♀ , INPA )
;
Tucurui , Puraquequara ,
11.viii.1980
, eq. Nunes de Mello leg . ( 2♀ , INPA )
.

Distribution ( Fig 4 ).
Colombia :Amazonas, Putumayo *; Ecuador : Napo ; Brazil : Acre , Amazonas, Goiás , Mato Grosso , Minas Gerais , Pará, Tocantins .

heading.emphasis:
Identification key for species of
Chartergus Lepeletier
(adapted from Richards 1978 )

paragraph.keyLead:
1. Central tubercle of metanotum very weak, often hardly noticeable ( Fig. 2B, E ); pronotum black, without anterior color band ( Fig. 2A, B, E, F ), prominence near ventral corner shorter and less acute but often more raised; metanotum with a pale band across the top half, rarely partly black..........................................
C. globiventris de Saussure, 1854

1’. Central tubercle of metanotum stronger ( Fig. 1B , 3B ); pronotum with anterior yellow band ( Fig. 1 A, B , 3 E, F ); metanotum nearly always entirely black or as above................................................................... 2

2. Metanotum nearly always entirely black or with small yellow spots on the sides; pronotum with anterior whitish yellow band, usually incomplete and stronger in the middle ( Fig. 3 E, F ); scrobal furrow with more or less regular cross-keels....................................................................................
C. metanotalis Richards, 1978

2. Metanotum with a pale band across the top half, rarely partly black here; pronotum with a complete anterior pale band ( Fig. 1 A, B ); scrobal furrow with less regular and usually weaker cross-keels........................
C. artifex (Christ, 1791)

subSection.paragraph:
Our phylogenetic analyses, based on MP and ML methods ( Fig. 5 ), using a concatenated matrix of morphological and COI mitochondrial data revealed the following relationship among the
Chartergus species
: (
C. globiventris
+ (
C. artifex
+
C. metanotalis
)), with high support (Symmetric Resampling support: 100 for MP; SH-aLRT: 99.4% and UFboot2: 92% for ML). The genus was supported in the MP analysis by two synapomorphies: the presence of the metanotal tubercle (character 2: 1) and the metasomal segment I being wider than long, compressed (character 13: 2), characteristic unique to
Chartergus
among all Epiponini.

About the phylogeny of
Chartergus
, the species with a very weak central tubercle of the metanotum, often barely noticeable (
C. globiventris
), was recovered at the base of the
Chartergus
clade (character 2: state 1). Conversely, the species with a stronger central tubercle of the metanotum were derived and placed as sister species (
C. artifex
+
C. metanotalis
) (character 2: state 2).
Chartergus globiventris
shows the apex of aedeagus moderate rounded (character 18: state 1) as autapomorphy, while
C. artifex
shows the apex of aedeagus strongly rounded (character 18: state 0), and
C. metanotalis
shows the apex of aedeagus partly truncate (character 18: state 2)

The phylogenetic analysis based on both morphological and molecular data provided valuable insights into the phylogenetic relationships of
Chartergus species.
The recovered phylogeny supported a monophyletic group, with
C . globiventris
positioned as the first lineage of the genus. These findings contribute to our understanding of the morphological variation and phylogenetic relationships of
Chartergus
.

We are thankful to Dr. Gavin Broad and Dr. Jaswinder Boparai for support in the Natural History Museum (London), Dr. Carlos Roberto Brand„o and Dra. Gabriela Camacho in Zoology Museum of Universidade de S„o Paulo, Dr. Marcio Luiz Oliveira and Dr. José Albertino Rafael for material and support in the Invertebrate Collection of Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia. AS is supported by a Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico (CNPq—PDE scholarship, process number 200731/2022-0). MA to Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior (CAPES) for research grant (88887.492572/2020-00), PCSB to CNPq (process numbers 200738/2022-4/SWE and 169022/2023-4) for scholarships. This study is also supported by CAPES—Finance Code 001.

subSection.paragraph: Supplementary Materials. The following supporting information can be downloaded at the DOI landing page of this paper:
Supplementary Table S1. Identification and access number in the GenBank of the Cox1 sequences used in the phylogenetic analyses.

Supplementary Material 1. Matrix consisting of 22 morphological characters, including 13 characters from adult females, six characters from adult males (including male genitalia), and three characters related to nest architecture.
Supplementary Material 2. Matrix consisting of 22 morphological characters + Cytochrome c oxidase I (COI) molecular data
List of Phenotypic Characters in This Work
1—Pronotum, pronotal fovea: present (0), absent (1);
2—Metanotum, metanotal tubercle: absent (0), present, weak (1), present, strong (2);
3—Eye, bristles: absent (0), long (1); short (2);
4—Clypeus, shape: longer than wide (0), wider than long (1);
5—Clypeus, lateral margin, region of contact with eye: convergent (0), parallel (1), divergent (2);
6—Clypeus, contact with eye, extent of the contact: greater than height of antennal socket (0), same height of antennal socket (1); shorter than height of antennal socket (2);
7—Gena, mid height in lateral view, width: narrower than half width of eye (0), wider than half width of eye (1); 8—Humeri, shape: rounded (0), produced (1);
9—Pronotum, pretegular carina: present (0), absent (1);
10—Pronotum, pronotal carina, development: completely (0), only center (1), evanescent (2);
11—Pronotum, lateral region, punctures: absent (0), present (1);
12—Pronotum, lateral region, distance between punctures: sparse (0), contiguous (1);
13—Metasomal segment I, shape: petiolate or longer than wide (0); wider than long, cap-shaped (1); wider than long, compressed (2);
14—Male, gena, width: narrowed (0), wide (1);
15—Male, metapleuron, top, rugosity: not rugose (0), rugose (1);
16—Paramere, apex, width: wider (0), narrower (1);
17—Paramere, parameral spine: stouter, protruding further (0), less stout protruding less far (1);
18—Aedeagus, apex, shape: strongly rounded (0), moderate rounded (1), partly truncate (2);
19—Aedeagus, beneath of center, process: with anterior projection (0), with interior tooth (1), no distinct anterior projection (2);
20—Nest, pedicel: absent (0), present (1);
21—Nest, envelope entrance, locality: ventral (0), multiple (1);
22—Nest, secondary envelopes: absent (0), present (1).
